    • "2 Apple Pencils: the standard and a short one that supports the iPhone and iPad mini"

  • 2.3: Federico picked "Apple Music will be redesigned again", score: 0
    • "Will gain more Spotify-like algorithmic features"
    • "An Apple version of the Daily Mix and a way to discover back catalog songs from artists you don't know (Discover Weekly?)"

    • The iPhone X and ARKit is deemed to fulfill this

  • 3.3: Stephen picked "Redesigned Mac Pro", score: 0.5

  • Myke: 1.5
  • Federico: 0.5

This starts out as "no prizes" for these predictions, just saying stuff and seeing what happens.

But after the event, when some are right and some are wrong, there is suddenly a lot more temptation to start grading and ranking.

Flexy Picks

    • "Maybe more of a hope"

  • 1.3: Federico picked "iWork updates for iOS 12", score: 0
  • 1.4: Federico picked "Cheaper phone is not called "iPhone 9"", score: 1
  • 1.5: Federico picked "New watch bands", score: 1
  • 1.6: Federico picked "Series 4 has multiple changes to watch faces", score: 1
    • "(beyond the leaked ones we have already seen)"
  • 2.1: Stephen picked "No iPads, iPhone and Apple Watch only", score: 1
  • 2.2: Stephen picked "No Macs", score: 1
  • 2.3: Stephen picked "Names will be XC and XS", score: 0
  • 2.4: Stephen picked "Line will be XS, 9, 8+, 8, 7+, 7, SE", score: 1
  • 2.5: Stephen picked "iPhone 9 will come in colors", score: 1
  • 3.1: Myke picked "New iPads", score: 0
  • 3.2: Myke picked "New pencil and keyboard", score: 0
  • 3.3: Myke picked "Nothing about the Mac", score: 1
    • The mention of Mojave's release is deemed insufficient to make this wrong.
  • 3.4: Myke picked "The cheaper iPhone will be called iPhone 9", score: 0
  • 3.5: Myke picked "The only iPhones seen on stage will be the ones we already know about", score: 1
  • 3.6: Myke picked "The larger iPhone will be called XS+", score: 0
  • 3.7: Myke picked "New and faster FaceID", score: 1
  • 3.8: Myke picked "A new, unique case", score: 0

The Scores

  • Stephen: 80%
  • Federico: 60% (not a typo)
  • Myke: 40%

As this wasn't expected to be strictly graded at first, there is some contention about how to grade the results. Federico advocates for weighing based on importance. Stephen argues for percentages. It is widely agreed that Myke has lost. Myke insists that as the loser, he picks the winner, and picks Stephen. Federico deems this a conspiracy. After some bickering, Myke declares that the scores are as above, and the issue is settled.

  • 1.3: Myke picked "Apple will launch a subscription service featuring original video content", score: 1
  • 2.1: Federico picked "iOS gets a tabbed windows feature that all apps can implement", score: 1

    • "(Not just additional iCloud space)"
    • The free AppleTV+ trial with new devices combined with an iPhone Upgrade Program purchase is deemed to not count during grading.

  • Federico: 4

2019 Media Event Predictions

jbiatek30th April 2021 at 8:49am
Keynote TableOfContents

The predictions: https://www.relay.fm/connected/235

The results: https://www.relay.fm/connected/236

The pick order was chosen randomly, but the results would go on to set the order for WWDC predictions, as announced in episode 234: a "qualifying round" using the rules of the annual predictions. That makes this the first of what we now call the Keynote Rickies.

Regular Picks

  • 1.1: Federico picked "Apple News service for magazines", score: 1
  • 1.2: Myke picked "Apple will announce a video streaming service", score: 1
    • "...which includes content from other providers, this will either be free content or paying for a subscription from within the app"
  • 1.3: Stephen picked "The video streaming service does not launch until at least May 1", score: 1
  • 2.1: Federico picked "Apple will also announce a service bundle to get multiple services for one integrated fee", score: 0
    • Ironically, this was deemed insufficiently risky to be a Risky Pick.
  • 2.2: Myke picked "Apple's original content will premiere after the service itself launches", score: 1
    • "non original content will come first, excluding existing programs"
  • 2.3: Stephen picked "Tim Cook interacts with a celebrity", score: 1

Risky Picks

  • 1: Federico picked "Apple will mention at least one new feature coming to the HomePod", score: -1
    • "HomePod" needs to be mentioned by name.
  • 2: Myke picked "Apple announces a video game subscription service", score: 2
  • 3: Stephen picked "Apple TV app will receive a refreshed design", score: 2

Scores

  • Stephen: 4
  • Myke: 4
  • Federico: 0

Stephen and Myke are tied, what to do? Federico wants to decide based on how risky he thinks their picks are, and that Myke should get the win. Myke would rather flip a coin.

Stephen proposes best of 3, Myke is heads. The results are heads, tails, heads.

Flexy Picks

  • 1.1: Federico picked "Apple News will expand internationally", score: 0
  • 1.2: Federico picked "Apple TV box gets a price cut", score: 0
  • 1.3: Federico picked "Apple gives a quick tour of improvements to next round of software updates", score: 0
  • 2.1: Myke picked "The video streaming service will come to Roku and Fire TV products", score: 1
  • 2.2: Myke picked "All the celebrities will come out at the end and take a picture together", score: 1
  • 3.1: Stephen picked "Major publications noticeably absent from News+", score: 1

These were non-graded picks for bragging rights, and indeed weren't ever graded officially.

WinnerMyke

2019 WWDC flip for second place

jbiatek29th April 2021 at 3:12pm
2019 WWDC Predictions Coin flip Tails

WinnerMyke
LoserFederico

2019 WWDC Predictions

jbiatek30th April 2021 at 5:34pm
Keynote TableOfContents

The predictions: https://www.relay.fm/connected/245

The results: https://www.relay.fm/connected/246 (live!)

In episode 245, Stephen mentions accidentally sending "Ricky" instead of "risky" in an iMessage, which ends up being a major shift in branding for the Connected predictions game.

Regular Picks

  • 1.1: Myke picked "Dark mode for iOS", score: 1
  • 1.2: Stephen picked "iOS 13 will change the system requirements, dropping devices supported by iOS 12", score: 1
  • 1.3: Federico picked "New Animoji in iOS 13", score: 1
    • Ungraded: Federico had some specific predictions which were not written down: at least 4, maybe 5, a demo on stage, would like to see kangaroo, peacock, squirrel, or white rat as new animals.
  • 2.1: Myke picked "Apple will mention Apple Arcade during the keynote", score: 1
  • 2.2: Stephen picked "Apple replaces at least one bundled macOS app with a Marzipan version", score: 1
    • It's called Catalyst, not Marzipan, which is pushed back on a little. Podcasts is cited as fulfilling this (is it replacing a Mac app? Stephen gets away with this a bit) and they say that Messages might now be a Catalyst app, but in fact it isn't.
    • The permissive grading may be due to the other hosts not wanting to get too picky when it comes to grading later picks.
  • 2.3: Federico picked "iOS gets expanded font support", score: 1

Risky Picks

  • 1: Myke picked "Cursor support for iOS", score: 2
    • Was not mentioned in the keynote, but more information came out during the week about the new accessibility feature.
  • 2: Stephen picked "The HomePod will gain multiple user support via voice detection", score: 2
  • 3: Federico picked "Apple will bring back some kind of "app list/launcher" UI element on iPad", score: 2
    • Federico cites parts of Slide Over's new multitasking interface, and when that doesn't seem to be working, says "If you don't give me this point, I will call the police." It escalates to the point of typing 911 into his phone.
    • "Some kind of" is vague enough to count this, and it definitely is not because of the threat.

Scores

  • Stephen: 4
  • Myke: 4
  • Federico: 4

It's a 3 way tie! How do you flip a coin between 3 people? A knockout tournament, where you "keep flipping until there's one man standing", apparently.

The rules are more clearly explained: each host will guess heads or tails, and then the coin will be flipped. Wrong answers are knocked out, unless all of them are wrong. Jason Snell comes on stage to handle things. He can't flip a coin, so he'll ask Siri.

For flip number 1, Myke and Federico pick heads, Stephen picks tails. The result is tails, knocking out Myke and Federico and giving Stephen the win.

Flip number 2 decides second place, with Federico taking heads. However, it is tails, putting Myke in second and Federico last.

Flexy Picks

  • 1.1: Myke picked "Apple does some new stuff with Animoji to make it more like Bitmoji", score: 1
  • 1.2: Stephen picked "Mail.app will get modern features like snoozing", score: 0.5
    • Threads can be muted, which isn't what he was talking about, really.
    • As these are "ungraded picks" being, uh, graded, Stephen is given a half point because why not.
  • 1.3: Federico picked "There will be changes to the drawing/sketching interface used for screenshots, notes, etc.", score: 1
    • "Maybe it will even be an API."
  • 2.1: Myke picked "External storage support on iOS", score: 1
  • 2.2: Stephen picked "iCloud family photo sharing", score: 0
  • 2.3: Federico picked "Improved support for ZIP archives in the Files app and framework", score: 1

The ungraded picks have mild stakes added: the loser must buy a round of drinks.

Flexy Scores

  • Stephen: 0.5 out of 2
  • Myke: 2 out of 2
  • Federico: 2 out of 2

Stephen owes drinks to the other two.

WinnerStephen

Regular Picks

  • 1.1: Federico picked "Apple will name a successor to Steve Dowling, former head of public relations at Apple", score: 0
    • "Either named by Apple officially, or reported by more than one outlet that a person has been appointed."
  • 1.2: Myke picked "The 2020 iPhone line will feature at least one 5G phone", score: 1
    • "Stephen is highly skeptical," Stephen jokingly predicts it will be called "iPhone 11S Pro Max 5G"
    • Before the prediction episode has even finished, news breaks that 5G service is coming to Stephen's own neighborhood.
  • 1.3: Stephen picked "The 13 inch MacBook Pro will gain a larger screen", score: 0
  • 2.1: Federico picked "At least one of the 2020 iPhones will have a higher refresh rate display (Pro Motion)", score: 0
  • 2.2: Myke picked "The iPad Pro line is updated before the iPhone with a hardware feature that's not on any current iPhone in 2019 or 2020", score: 1
    • Myke says during grading that he originally expected 5G to get him this point but LIDAR did instead, but he actually focused on LIDAR when originally explaining this pick. (During the grading, Federico delivers his impromptu review of the 2020 iPad Pro.)
  • 2.3: Stephen picked "Apple will launch its own podcast content beyond its existing deal with Oprah", score: 1

Risky Picks

  • 1: Federico picked "Apple will release at least 1 new pro app for iPad that we haven't previously seen on iPad", score: -1
    • "(The app can be universal.)"
  • 2: Myke picked "The notch on the iPhone will get physically smaller in at least one of the 2020 iPhones", score: 2
    • Grading for this was tricky, but Stephen discovered that the Apple Accessory Design Guidelines indicate that the notch got very slightly smaller, by millimeters, mostly due to the switch from LCD to OLED in the iPhone 12. The consensus is that it's a technical victory but not an honorable one.
  • 3: Stephen picked "Apple Podcast app launches on Android", score: -1

Scores

  • Stephen: 0
  • Myke: 4
  • Federico: -1

Flexy Picks

  • 1.1: Federico picked "Shortcuts will gain folders and/or new ways to run Shortcuts", score: 1
  • 1.2: Myke picked "Apple will announce a new services bundle", score: 1
  • 1.3: Stephen picked "WWDC brings no real changes to Mac Catalyst", score: 0
  • 2.1: Federico picked "The iPad home screen will continue to change with new elements and additions", score: 0
  • 2.2: Myke picked "Apple will introduce a new iMac design with an accompanying external display", score: 0
  • 2.3: Stephen picked "Apple will not ship an ARM Mac in 2020", score: 0
    • In 2019, Stephen picked the first ARM Mac to be shipped, so this was his... revenge?

Stephen coins "The Flexies" in the 2020 prediction episode.

In the year between making the picks and grading them, the Flexies became a game of their own with money on the line, but the new Flexy rules were not applied retroactively to this year's Flexy picks. "That would just be silly" and "We're not savages", after all. As a result, these Flexies are just two rounds of predictions for bragging rights.

WinnerMyke

About

jbiatek2nd May 2021 at 5:09pm
TableOfContents

This exercise in nerdery about nerdery was put together by me, Jason Biatek (pronounced "bee-attic").

Corrections and additional information are more than welcome. Open an issue on GitHub preferably, or you can also email me at [my first name] at [my last name] dot net. The interface of this page may look editable in some places, but those changes won’t be saved, they’re just in your browser.

This page is built with TiddlyWiki, which is a nifty single page wiki tool with lots of options for taking little bits of information and composing them together in different ways. When I realized that, my mind jumped to the many, many little bits of information in The Rickies, and I just had to try it out.

Myke proposes an audio predictions game, to be graded at the end of 2019.

Regular Picks

  • 1: Myke picked "AirPods to gain more controls via touch actions", score: 1
  • 2: Stephen picked "At least 1 more color option comes to AirPods", score: 0
  • 3: Federico picked "The AirPods line is split in two, and the lower end version gets a price drop", score: 0
    • The additional condition is an intentionally risky choice by Federico
    • Ultimately this is in fact his undoing, AirPods never officially get cut from their original $159 price.
  • 4: Myke picked "The next HomePod is a mini HomePod", score: 0
    • True, but too late. The HomePod mini wasn't released until 2020.
  • 5: Stephen picked "HomePod price drop", score: 1
    • In April, they were cut from $349 to $299.
  • 6: Federico picked "Shortcuts will gain new HomePod/AirPlay 2 actions to play audio on HomePod more quickly", score: 1
  • 7: Myke picked "Apple will create some new noise-cancelling technology", score: 1
    • Some sort of thing that they put into an AirPod or something that they tout as invented by Apple, is how it was clarified during predictions.
    • Myke, in absentia, gets the benefit of the doubt as to how new the AirPods Pro tech is.
  • 8: Stephen picked "Better incorporation of Apple News into the audio ecosystem", score: 0
    • For example, asking Siri for the news on a HomePod
    • This did eventually happen, but in 2020.
  • 9: Federico picked "HeadPods will be wireless only and they will have no headphone jack and will charge via Lightning or USB-C", score: 0

  • Stephen: 1
  • Myke: 2
  • Federico: 1

The Bill of Rickies

jbiatek2nd May 2021 at 10:41am
TableOfContents

Last amended January 13, 2021.

There are two types of Rickies: Annual Rickies and Keynote Rickies. The winner of the Annual Rickies is named the Annual Chairman, and retains the rights to the corresponding Twitter account for the full year. This position is awarded every January. The Keynote Rickies winner is named the Keynote Chairman, and retains the rights to the corresponding Twitter account until the next keynote is held.

Annual winners roll over to preserve the order of picks, for example the 2019 annual winner gets to go first for the next annual picks. Order for the Keynote Rickies is based on the previous Apple event. The Loser goes last.

To earn any points, everything written down in the prediction document must come true. No half points may be awarded in any round, and picks cannot be reused. One point is awarded for any pick deemed correct in the first two rounds. Two points will be awarded for correct picks in the Risky Pick round. If your Risky Pick is wrong, you lose a point. The two other hosts must agree that your pick is "risky".

For Keynote Rickies, the scoring window starts when the event begins and closes when the picks are scored. The winner of the regular and Risky picks must be granted access to the Annual or Event Chairman Twitter account, and will retain access until another winner is named.

The loser of the Flexies must compensate the winner of the Flexies by donating to the charity of the winner's choice. The amount of the donation is $25 per wrong Flexy made by the loser. In the case of a tie, the ratio of correct to incorrect Flexies will be taken into account[1]. Each host must make a minimum of 5 Flexy Picks. Flexies may be reused as future Flexies or regular picks. The money, of course, must be donated on air.

Changes

  • 328: "Non-graded" removed from the Flexy rules by listener request.
  • 327: Clarified the difference between Keynote and Annual Chairmanships.
  • 316: Myke notices that the rules do not identify when keynote picks can come true, and proposes that the window open at the start of the event and close at grading. (He also noted this in 311 and proposed the same rule change, but it was never written down.) Stephen prefers starting at the publication of the prediction episode, but Federico breaks the tie in Myke's favor, agreeing that it is a competition about the event. Unlike the Keynote Draft on Upgrade, which only allows information from the presentation itself, ancillary material is allowed. For example, a specifications page that clarifies details may figure into grading as long as it is available at that time.
  • 316: Clarified that Flexies may be reused (technically the "no reuse" rule wasn't in the Flexies section anyway, but it was agreed that banning their reuse would be too limiting).
  • 312: Donations for the Flexies must be done on the air after Stephen chooses to do so.
  • 311: The existing Chairman Twitter accounts are explicitly added to the written rules.
  • 311: The Flexy rules are simplified back down to just a donation to charity, dropping the additional gift to the winner.
  • 311: The title of "Chairman Ricky" is rephrased as "Keynote Chairman" and "Annual Chairman".
  • 300: The "ratio" based tiebreaker for the Flexies is added, and then the ideas start flowing. Instead of just buying drinks for the winner, bigger financial stakes are added. After much debate, the final decision is that the loser must pay both $25 per wrong Flexy to the winner's choice of charity and also purchase a surprise for the winner of the same amount. A 5 Flexy minimum is added. "tondog" in the Discord coins "The Bill of Rickies".
  • 275: The practice of separating annual picks and event picks for the purpose of pick order was codified in the written rules, after being discussed in 260. Stephen coins “The Flexies”.
  • 259: Myke proposes naming the competition "The Rickies", after Stephen's now infamous typo. The rule about the previous winner going first is revised. The title for the winner is "Chairman Ricky".
  • 245: Stephen said "Ricky" instead of "risky" in an iMessage, and now they're Ricky Picks. The loser of the non-graded picks has to buy drinks at the WWDC live show.
  • 244: "Everything written down must come true" added.
  • 243: No reuse of picks added as a new rule.
  • 236: This was never written down as a rule, but the practice of resolving ties with Siri coin flips was established.
  • 224: At some point in 2018, apparently Federico insisted that half points be banned.
  • 174: The Risky Pick round emerges fully formed from Federico's head after he hears Myke describe wanting to go big with a very specific pick. Two points for a correct pick and loss of a point for an incorrect one, to be implemented for the first time in the 2018 annual predictions.
  • 123: The first "predictions draft", used "round robin" ordering in 3 rounds. Picks were not allowed to be too "simple", like "Apple will release an iPhone", they must be specific. Myke decides, apparently on the spot, that these predictions will be checked at the end of the year to pick a winner.

Notes

[1]: I find this wording a little unclear, but there is enough precedence to explain it differently. The winner of the Flexies is the one with the most correct Flexy picks. If there is a tie, then the next tie breaker is the one with the fewest incorrect Flexy picks. The grading in episode 300, where this rule is established, is probably also the clearest application of it, with Myke's 1 out of 4 beating Federico's 1 out of 7. As stated in that clip, making more Flexy picks gives more chances to be right, making it easier to win based on sheer number of correct picks, but has the risk of a worse ratio in case of a tie (and, now that money is involved, a risk of much more money being owed in case of an outright loss).

In subsequent episodes, our beloved hosts sometimes have trouble remembering the details, and sometimes seem to instead be grading the Flexies entirely based on ratio, which is incorrect, but the results are the same when everyone picks 5-6 Flexies as they have so far.

No host has attempted something like this yet, but this could lead to a contentious scenario if a host attempts a high-risk "shotgun" strategy. A host getting 7 out of 20 will likely have to argue for his victory against another host who got none wrong but only made 6 picks. But based on the precedent set when the rule was written, and the letter of the text in the current rules, that’s the correct outcome.
